facts.text: Appeal from the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta Civil Appeal No. LI of 1949

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the High Court of Judicature at Calcut- ta Civil Appeal No. LI of 1949. Manohar Lal,  H.K. Mitter with him , for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by FAZL ALI J. on March 14, 1950

anchor.surface_text: 1950. March 14. The judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by FAZL ALI J.---The only question to be decided in this appeal, which arises out

facts.text: Appeal arises out of an execution proceeding

anchor.surface_text: ered by FAZL ALI J.---The only question to be decided in this appeal, which arises out of an execution proceeding, is whether the decree under execution is barred by limitation.

facts.text: First court held that the decree was not barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: The first companyrt held that the decree was number barred, but the High Court has companye to the opposite companyclusion, and the decree-holder has, after obtaining a certificate under Section 110 of the Civil Procedure Code, appealed to this Court.

facts.text: High Court held that the decree was barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: The first companyrt held that the decree was number barred, but the High Court has companye to the opposite companyclusion, and the decree-holder has, after obtaining a certificate under Section 110 of the Civil Procedure Code, appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Decree-holder obtained certificate under Section 110 CPC and appealed to Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: the decree-holder has, after obtaining a certificate under Section 110 of the Civil Procedure Code, appealed to this Court. The facts may be briefly stated as follows.

facts.text: Preliminary mortgage decree passed ex parte on 21 August 1940 in suit by appellant to enforce mortgage

anchor.surface_text: The facts may be briefly stated as follows. On the 21st August, 1940, a preliminary mortgage decree was passed ex parte in a suit instituted by the appellant to enforce a mortgage.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor applied under Order IX rule 13 CPC on 19 September 1940 to set aside ex parte decree

anchor.surface_text: On the 19th September, 1940, the judg- ment-debtor made an application under Order IX, rule 13, of the Civil Procedure Code for setting aside the ex parte decree, but this application was rejected on the 7th June, 1941.

facts.text: Application under Order IX rule 13 rejected on 7 June 1941

anchor.surface_text: ment-debtor made an application under Order IX, rule 13, of the Civil Procedure Code for setting aside the ex parte decree, but this application was rejected on the 7th June, 1941.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor filed application under Section 36 Bengal Money Lenders Act on 11 July 1941 to reopen preliminary decree

anchor.surface_text: On the 11th July, 1941, the judgment-debtor filed an application under Section a6 of the Bengal Money lenders Act, for reopening the preliminary decree, but this applica- tion was dismissed for default of appearance on the 20th December, 1941.

facts.text: Application under Section 36 dismissed for default on 20 December 1941

anchor.surface_text: tion was dismissed for default of appearance on the 20th December, 1941. Thereafter, a final mortgage decree was passed in favour of the appellant, on the 22nd December.

facts.text: Final mortgage decree passed in favour of appellant on 22 December 1941

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, a final mortgage decree was passed in favour of the appellant, on the 22nd December. The judgment-debtor then made an application under Order IX, rule 9, of the Civil Procedure Code for the restoration of the proceedings under Section 36 of the Money lenders Act.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor applied under Order IX rule 9 CPC for restoration of proceedings under Section 36 Money Lenders Act

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor then made an application under Order IX, rule 9, of the Civil Procedure Code for the restoration of the proceedings under Section 36 of the Money lenders Act.

facts.text: Application under Order IX rule 9 dismissed on 1 June 1942 on grounds of insufficient cause and no purpose after final decree

anchor.surface_text: The application. was however dismissed on the 1 st June, 1942, both on the ground that numbersufficient cause for the numberappearance of the applicant and his failure to take steps in the proceedings was shown and on the ground that numberpurpose would be served by reopening the preliminary decree after the final decree had been passed.

facts.text: Judgment-debtor preferred appeal to High Court from dismissal of Order IX rule 9 application

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtor thereafter preferred an appeal to the High Court at Calcutta from the decision dismissing his application under Order IX, rule 9, but the appeal was dismissed for number-prosecution, on the 3rd July, 1944.

facts.text: Appeal to High Court dismissed for non-prosecution on 3 July 1944

anchor.surface_text: but the appeal was dismissed for number-prosecution, on the 3rd July, 1944. On the 9th April, 1945, the appellant filed an application for executing the decree against the original judgment-debtor, though he had died previously,

facts.text: Appellant filed execution application on 9 April 1945 against original judgment-debtor who had died previously

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th April, 1945, the appellant filed an application for executing the decree against the original judgment-debtor, though he had died previously, and this application was dismissed for default on the 11th May, 1945.

facts.text: Original judgment-debtor had died before 9 April 1945

anchor.surface_text: the appellant filed an application for executing the decree against the original judgment-debtor, though he had died previously, and this application was dismissed for default

facts.text: Execution application of 9 April 1945 dismissed for default on 11 May 1945

anchor.surface_text: and this application was dismissed for default on the 11th May, 1945. On the 2nd June, 1945, the present application for execution was filed,

facts.text: Present execution application filed on 2 June 1945

anchor.surface_text: On the 2nd June, 1945, the present application for execution was filed, and the question which we have to decide is whether this application is in time.

facts.text: Execution application filed more than three years after final decree

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that the application for execution having been made more than three years after the date of the final decree, it must be held to be timebarred,

facts.text: Appellant contends case falls under clause 2 or 3 of article 182 Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: unless, as has been companytended before us, the case falls under either clause 2 or clause 3 of article 182 of the Indian Limitation Act.

facts.text: Appellant contends application under Section 36 Money Lenders Act is application for review under clause 3 article 182

anchor.surface_text: It is companytended that the case is companyered by clause 3,and the ground urged in support of this companytention is that the application made by the judgment-debtor for reopening the preliminary mortgage decree under Section 36 of the Money- lenders Act must be regarded as an application for review

facts.text: Court holds application under Section 36 was not a review as court never undertook to review the decree

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is numbersubstance in this companyten- tion. The important words in clause 3 of article 182 are 1  where there has been a review and  2  the decision passed on the review . These words show that before a case can be brought under article 182,clause 8, it must be shown firstly that the companyrt had undertaken to review the relevant decree or order and sec- ondly, that there has been a decision.on.the review.

facts.text: Application under Section 36 for reopening preliminary decree dismissed for default

anchor.surface_text: What actual- ly happened was that the application under Section a6 for reopening the preliminary decree  number the final decree which is the decree sought to be executed  was dismissed for default

facts.text: Application under Order IX rule 9 for restoration of Section 36 proceedings also dismissed

anchor.surface_text: and the application under Order IX, rule 9, of.the Civil Procedure Code for the restoration of the proceedings under Section 86 of the Money lenders Act was also dis- missed.

certificate under Section 110 of the Civil Procedure Code, appealed to this Court. The facts may be briefly stated as follows. On the 21st August, 1940, a preliminary mortgage decree was passed ex parte in a suit instituted by the appellant to enforce a mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that the application for execution having been made more than three years after the date of the final decree, it must be held to be timebarred,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is application was dismissed for default on the 11th May, 1945. On the 2nd June, 1945, the present application for execution was filed, and the questi

arguments.court_reasoning: No substance in contention regarding clause 3; clause 2 not addressed specifically but overall rejected as decree held barred

arguments.claim: The case is covered by clause 3 of article 182 as the application under Section 36 of the Bengal Money Lenders Act must be regarded as an application for review

anchor.surface_text: It is contended that the case is covered by clause 3,and the ground urged in support of this contention is that the application made by the judgment-debtor for reopening the preliminary mortgage decree under Section 36 of the Money- lenders Act must be regarded as an application for review and time should be held to run from the date of the final order passed in the proceedings connected with that applica-

court_response_anchor.surface_text: is application was dismissed for default on the 11th May, 1945. On the 2nd June, 1945, the present application for execution was filed, and the questi

arguments.court_reasoning: No substance; requires court to have undertaken review and decision thereon; here dismissed for default without review undertaken

arguments.claim: Clause 3 of article 182 requires that there has been a review by the court undertaking to review the decree and a decision passed on the review

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no substance in this contention. The important words in clause 3 of article 182 are 1  where there has been a review and  2  the decision passed on the review . These words show that before a case can be brought under article 182,clause 3, it must be shown firstly that the court had undertaken to review the relevant decree or order and secondly, that there has been a decision.on.the review.

arguments.claim: Even assuming broad interpretation of 'review' to include Section 36 application, the court never undertook to review the decree as it was dismissed for default and restoration application also dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, even if it be assumed that the word review has been used in article 182 in a large sense and that the application for reopening the decree under Section 36 of the Bengal Money lenders Act was an application for review, the appellant cannot succeed, because the court never undertook or purported to review the decree in question. What actually happened was that the application under Section 36 for reopening the preliminary decree  not the final decree which is the decree sought to be executed  was dismissed for default

holdings.text: The application for execution is time-barred as it was made more than three years after the date of the final decree and the case does not fall under clause 2 or clause 3 of article 182 of the Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that the application for execution having been made more than three years after the date of the final decree, it must be held to be timebarred, unless, as has been contended before us, the case falls under either clause 2 or clause 3 of article 182 of the Indian Limitation Act. Under these clauses, time to make the application begins to run from--

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 182 provides 3-year limitation from final decree unless extended by appeal or review; extensions under cl 2/3 rejected as no qualifying appeal or review

holdings.text: There is no substance in the contention that the case is covered by clause 3 of article 182

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no substance in this contention. The important words in clause 3 of article 182 are 1 where there has been a review and 2 the decision passed on the review . These words show that before a case can be brought under article 182,clause 3, it must be shown firstly that the court had undertaken to review the relevant decree or order and secondly, that there has been a decision.on.the review.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 3 requires actual review undertaken by court and decision thereon; petitioner's equation of s.36 application to review rejected

holdings.text: Clause 3 of article 182 applies only where the court has undertaken to review the relevant decree or order and there has been a decision passed on the review

anchor.surface_text: These words show that before a case can be brought under article 182,clause 3, it must be shown firstly that the court had undertaken to review the relevant decree or order and secondly, that there has been a decision.on.the review.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of key phrases 'where there has been a review' and 'the decision passed on the review' mandates court action and decision

holdings.text: The court never undertook or purported to review the decree as the s.36 application for reopening the preliminary decree (not the final decree under execution) was dismissed for default and the restoration application under O.IX r.9 was also dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, even if it be assumed that the word review has been used in article 182 in a large sense and that the application for reopening the decree under Section 36 of the Bengal Money lenders Act was an application for review, the appellant cannot succeed, because the court never undertook or purported to review the decree in question. What actually- ly happened was that the application under Section 36 for reopening the preliminary decree  not the final decree which is the decree sought to be executed  was dismissed for default

holdings.reasoning_summary: No court review undertaken; dismissal for default without merits consideration; targeted preliminary not final decree; restoration also failed

holdings.text: Even assuming 'review' under article 182 includes an application to reopen under s.36 Bengal Money Lenders Act, the appellant cannot succeed

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, even if it be assumed that the word review has been used in article 182 in a large sense and that the application for reopening the decree under Section 36 of the Bengal Money lenders Act was an application for review, the appellant cannot succeed, because the court never undertook or purported to review the decree in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical broad interpretation of 'review' does not help as no court undertaking of review occurred

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is numbersubstance in this companyten- tion. The important words in clause 3 of article 182 are 1  where there has been a review and  2  the decision passed on the review . These words show that before a case can be brought under article 182,clause 8, it must be shown firstly that the companyrt had undertaken to review the relevant decree or order and sec- ondly, that there has been a decision.on.the review.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's contention that the execution application is saved by Article 182 clause 3 rejected; appellant cannot succeed as court did not undertake review of decree

In our opinion, there is numbersubstance in this companyten- tion. The important words in clause 3 of article 182 are 1  where there has been a review and  2  the decision passed on the review . These words show that before a case can be brought under article 182,clause 8, it must be shown firstly that the companyrt had undertaken to review the relevant decree or order and sec- ondly, that there has been a decision.on.the review.

What actually- ly happened was that the application under Section 36 for reopening the preliminary decree  not the final decree which is the decree sought to be executed  was dismissed for default
